top_comment.text:
I would love to know what you feed your cats!  I have 2 cats and in the 
morning i give them vet wet food mixed with pumpkin and topped with a 
special treat sometimes, however I do leave a small amount of dry food out, 
which is usually still there when I return from work.  However I have 
learned that people are feeding some of their cats actual meat from stores, 
cooked or raw I don't know.  What is better?  And do you recommend grain 
free food? Lots of questions sorry, I just haven't heard what you feed your 
cats yet.﻿
top_comment.author: Gereen Anderson

comments.text: Thank you!! I will do this!
comments.author: Gereen Anderson

comments.text:
Jackson has several behavior articles on LittleBigCat(.)com that he shares 
with Dr. Jean Hofve. Dr. Jean has info on optimal nutrition and health for 
cats based on what cats are designed by nature to eat. Much of the feeding 
info is similar to the non-commercial and highly recommended Catinfo(.)org 
by Dr. Lisa Pierson.

This info has saved many cats' lives, including our neighbor's cat and 
others. I've noticed that our cats are healthier than most "clinic cats" 
I've seen living at various vet offices.  This info can help you save money 
on cat food and will help you save on vet bills. (Be sure to read the 
excerpt from Dr. Pierson's paper on "prescription diets"!).
comments.author: ACCCGStThomas

top_comment.text:
My cats identify breakfast and dinner times with their own alarm clock. 
They won't go crazy for dinner until they hear the alarm, no matter what 
the time.﻿
top_comment.author: Sun & Schrody

comments.text:
+mirawenya It rings and I start preparing the food. I take the can out of 
the fridge and they know it's time. :)
comments.author: Sun & Schrody

comments.text:
(My cats tend to pester me for an hour before feeding time... Like try to 
trip me over type things. While it can be cute when they get all cuddly, it 
also gets annoying at times. Especially with the threat of death while 
walking.)
comments.author: mirawenya

comments.text:
Does food appear on the plate at that time, or does it ring, and you go 
prepare the food?
comments.author: mirawenya

comments.text:
+hawkechik Same, it's an alarm on my phone. :) Mine is the Meow Mix song 
hahahaha.
comments.author: Sun & Schrody

top_comment.text:
Daylight savings time is really stupid and soooooooo unnecessary. Messes up 
with everyone.﻿
top_comment.author: An telwi

comments.text:
Don't really know how it is for you guys, but here in sweden the daylight 
is fucking us up enough as it is. As much light as possible during winter 
and as dark nights as possible during summer is very much appreciated :)
comments.author: Lisa Lipkin

comments.text:
I totally agree.  We NO longer need Daylight Savings time.  It was for the 
farmers when they needed their children's help in the fields before going 
to school.  We don't need it.  Also, it doesn't help on saving any energy 
either.  Get rid of Daylight Savings time.  What do we need to do to get it 
stopped forever?
comments.author: Fay Hafer

comments.text:
Depends where you live. I prefer not to have the sun shinning in my eyes @ 
0430 waking me up.
comments.author: limpnail

captions.text: It's time.
It's time, it's all about time.
Tic-tock, folks.
Time.
Is that a big enough hint?
It's time to get catified.
Let's Go.

What I want to talk about
today is, technically,

the concept of
daylight savings time.

Spring ahead, fall
back, you know?

There's a time every year
where we switch our clocks,

technically, to compensate
for increasing or decreasing
sunlight.

Now, here's the thing, you
might find this really strange,

but I'm sure you've noticed
that your cats go pretty wonky
right around this time.

So really, we're going to talk
about circadian rhythm, body
clock.

We all have a program
notion of what
happens in a 24-hour time span.
Let's talk about cats.
Just the raw cat.

Let's break it down, cat
mojo 101, the raw cat.

What is in the back
of a cat's head?

Well, we know that
they're sleeping in order

to gear up for the
hunt, and they wake up,
and they're ready.

How do they know when to
sleep and when to hunt?

Well, part of it's
programmed into them.
They're corpuscular beings.

Their natural prey is out during
the dusk and dawn hours, right?

So , if you're a cat, you know
that the vowls, and the mice,

and every other little creepy
crawly around the garden are up
and at em at dusk and dawn.

So that makes cats
just programed

to do that dusk
and dawn hunting.

The circadian rhythm of cats,
and studies have shown this,
are totally affected by us.

So there's the natural
raw cat circadian rhythm

here, dusk and dawn,
dusk and dawn, hunt,

catch, kill, eat
it, dust and dawn.

And then there's
this, us, humans.

So the difference
between a cat who

is allowed to just be in the
house and roam in and out,

in and out, all day,
and a cat that's in,

let's say an apartment,
where maybe they

have structured time out
for a couple of hours a day.

There's a huge difference
in when they're up and down.

When you and your family
get up in the morning, boom.

Energetically,
everything explodes.

Of course, the cat's
going to explode with you.

The same thing happens
when you guys come home
from work and school.

Now, as we approach daylight
savings time, what happens?

The thing is that cats are
incredibly routine oriented.

Now, how do they
determine what's on time
and what's not on time?

As I've said, because
they're corpuscular,
it's the position of the sun.

So, if you've ever
noticed, your cat
follows the sun during the day.

They'll go to one window
where the sun is coming up

and as the sun moves,
so do your cats move.

So what happens when we turn
the clocks ahead or back?

Well, at 5:30, let's say, when
it was starting to get dark,

your cat knows it's
dinner time and they
start hounding you for dinner.

Well, it's not
really dinnertime,
it's really too early right now.

So, what we do, mistake-wise
I think, is we acquiesce.

We say oh, you know, I get it,
you're hungry, let me feed you.

As we approach daylight
savings time, remember, ,

keep your routines the same,
that your cat will adjust.

Let's remember something, cats
are a slave to their own grind.

The cat's social
structure, their

needs to eat, and hunt, and
play, and when they sleep,

all depend on the
position of the sun.

Studies show that
cats actually sleep

just about 10 hours
a day, sometimes 12.
That's it.

You know what they're
doing the rest of the time?
They're looking out the window.

They're following the
sun as the day goes on.

You are responsible for keeping
your cats rhythm intact.

So, when daylight savings
time comes, just stick to it.

Remember, it's like
your cats have jet lag,

and if you had a child with jet
lag, what what would you do?

Would you feed them lunch
at 4 o'clock in the morning?
No.

What you would do is just tell
them, it's all going to be OK,

but we're going to keep
our structure as it is.

Think about this, it's not
only the position of the sun,
but it's the moon as well.

Have you ever notice
that around the full moon

your cats go insane because
suddenly there's so much more
light coming into your home.
What can you do about it?
That's your homework.

Your homework for
daylight savings

time starts now, before
daylight savings time kicks in,

before the switch in
the clocks happen.

What you need to do is get
your cats into a routine.

This is why I'm so big on
feeding your cats meals and not

allowing them to free
feed around the house.

Not only do you want to
keep their rhythm together

when it comes to eating,
and playing, and sleeping,

but think about where
they sleep during the day.

Expose of as much sun sleepy
spots as you possibly can.

Put those scent soakers
out around the windows,

because again, your cat
creates a sundial of where

they go during the day based
on the position of the sun.
Keep windows open.

Make sure that your cats have
light, plenty of it as well,

and I'm telling you, you
will see great changes
in your cats behavior.

And you're going to need
this, because the next time

on cat mojo I'm going to talk
to you about how you can sleep

through the night when
your cat doesn't want
you to sleep through the night.
Oh, that's a good one.

Now, in the meantime,
please leave comments.

Let me know what
you're thinking about.

Let me know about the
questions you might have.

The more questions I get, the
more that get answered, man.

Besides that, I want
you to stay tuned.

We have Google Hangout coming
up at the end of this month

where you can ask
me questions live.

We've got the premiere of
"My Cat From Hell" coming up
in the next couple of months.

I'll keep you informed
on that, but you'll only

know all of this stuff
if you subscribe.

Hey, watch the
Animalist Network,

there's fun stuff on
here every single day.

Find me on Google and Facebook,
cause I am where you are,
and I am where the cats are.

Anyhow, until next
time, all light,
all love, all mojo to ya.
Mwah, I love ya.

title: Why Your Cat Goes Crazy During Daylight Savings Time
